title: 113_hr4065
content: The Act may be cited as the "Smartphone Theft Prevention Act". Congress finds that mobile device theft costs consumers $30 billion annually, with 1 in 3 robberies involving mobile device theft. Efforts have been made by carriers, manufacturers, law enforcement, and the FCC to address this issue, but more action is needed. Consumers deserve the most secure technology to protect their information, and advancements in technological protections benefit the economy, consumers, and public safety. The wireless industry should collaborate with law enforcement to educate consumers on security tools. Technological protections are evolving to benefit the economy, consumers, and public safety. The wireless industry should educate consumers on security tools, and collaboration with law enforcement is essential. The mobile device industry, law enforcement, and consumer advocates should proactively develop solutions to protect consumers and drive innovation. SEC. 343. FUNCTION FOR STOLEN MOBILE DEVICES. Part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a provision for stolen mobile devices. The section defines terms related to mobile devices, including 'account holder', 'commercial mobile data service', 'commercial mobile service', and 'mobile device'. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 defines terms related to mobile devices, including 'commercial mobile service' and 'mobile device'. Providers of commercial mobile service must offer a function on the device for the account holder to remotely delete or render inaccessible their information. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 requires providers of commercial mobile service to offer a function on the device for the account holder to remotely delete or render inaccessible their information, make the device inoperable on any network globally, and prevent reactivation without authorization. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 mandates that devices must have features to remotely delete data, render the device inoperable globally, and prevent unauthorized reactivation or reprogramming. Additionally, the device must be able to reverse these actions if recovered by the account holder. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 requires mobile devices to have remote data deletion, global device disablement, and prevention of unauthorized reactivation. Devices must also be able to reverse these actions if recovered by the account holder. Additionally, manufacturers or importers in the US must ensure that mobile devices allow service providers to offer these functions. The Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 mandates mobile devices to have specific functions like remote data deletion and global device disablement. The Commission can exempt mobile service providers or manufacturers/importers from these requirements if they offer functionally equivalent technology on the device. The Commission may exempt manufacturers or importers from specific mobile device requirements if they provide technology on the device that achieves the same function. Additionally, waivers can be granted for low-cost, voice-only mobile devices. The Commission may waive requirements for low-cost, voice-only mobile devices that focus on text messaging. Providers cannot charge fees for essential functions on mobile devices. The FCC may waive requirements for low-cost, voice-only mobile devices that focus on text messaging. Providers cannot charge fees for essential functions on mobile devices, and violators may face forfeiture penalties determined by the Commission. The FCC may impose forfeiture penalties on violators, in addition to any other penalties, for not complying with requirements related to mobile devices. Manufacturers and providers can still take actions to protect consumers from mobile device theft. The term "mobile device" is defined in the Communications Act of 1934. The FCC can penalize violators for not complying with mobile device requirements. The term "mobile device" is defined in the Communications Act of 1934, and the Act applies to devices manufactured or imported for sale in the US after January 1, 2015. Compliance extensions may be granted by the FCC. The FCC can exempt individuals from compliance requirements for a temporary period if they need more time to comply with the regulations.
